Detailed Description

Class SNES_SAMRAIContext provides an interface to the SNES nonlinear solver capabilities in PETSc to facilitate their use with SAMRAI. While PETSc is implemented in an object-based manner, this class makes it easier to use PETSc's routines with SAMRAI data structures. In particular, it hides from the user some of the messy details required to link the C++ class library with PETSc which is written in C and to override PETSc objects, like vectors, with those found in SAMRAI.

This class declares five private static member functions to link user-defined routines for nonlinear residual calculation, Jacobian evaluation, preconditioner setup and solve, and Jacobian-vector product operations. The implementation of these functions is defined by the user in a subclass of the abstract base class SNESAbstractFunctions. The vector objects used within the solver are provided by the PETSc_SAMRAIVectorReal wrapper class.

Input Parameters

If no parameters are read from input, PETSc defaults are used. See the PETSc documentation (http://www-unix.mcs.anl.gov/petsc/). for more information on default parameters and SNES functionality.

Definitions:

  • maximum_nonlinear_iterations maximum number of nonlinear iterations
  • maximum_function_evals maximum number of nonlinear function evaluations
  • uses_preconditioner whether or not a preconditioner is used in the solution of the Newton equations.
  • uses_explicit_jacobian whether or not the user provides code to explicitly calculate Jacobian-vector products.
  • absolute_tolerance absolute nonlinear convergence tolerance
  • relative_tolerance relative nonlinear convergence tolerance
  • step_tolerance minimum tolerance on change in solution norm between nonlinear iterations
  • forcing_term_strategy forcing term choice for linear solvers within the inexact Newton method.
  • constant_forcing_term constant relative convergence tolerance in Krylov solver
  • initial_forcing_term initial relative convergence tolerance in Krylov solver (used in Eisenstat-Walker case).
  • maximum_forcing_term maximum relative convergence tolerance in Krylov solver (used in Eisenstat-Walker case).
  • EW_choice2_alpha power used in Eisenstat-Walker choice 2 relative convergence tolerance computation.
  • EW_choice2_gamma multiplicative factor used in Eisenstat-Walker choice 2 relative convergence tolerance computation.
  • EW_safeguard_exponent power for safeguard used in Eisenstat-Walker choice 2
  • EW_safeguard_disable_threshold threshold for imposing safeguard in Eisenstat-Walker choice 2.
  • linear_solver_type value for type of linear solver.
  • linear_solver_absolute_tolerance absolute convergence tolerance in linear solver
  • linear_solver_divergence_tolerance amount linear solver residual can increase before solver concludes method is diverging
  • maximum_linear_iterations maximum number of linear solver iterations
  • maximum_gmres_krylov_dimension maximum dimension of Krylov subspace before restarting. Valid only if GMRES is used as the linear solver.
  • gmres_orthogonalization_algorithm algorithm used to incrementally construct the orthonormal basis of the Krylov subspace used by GMRES. Valid only if GMRES is used as the linear solver
  • differencing_parameter_strategy strategy used for computing the differencing parameter when Jacobian-vector products are approximated via finite differences
  • function_evaluation_error square root of the estimated relative error in function evaluation

All values read in from a restart database may be overriden by input database values. If no new input database value is given, the restart database value is used.

Parameter read from restart db may be overridden by input db

A sample input file entry might look like:

    absolute_tolerance             = 10.e-10
    relative_tolerance             = 10.e-6
    step_tolerance                 = 10.e-8
    maximum_nonlinear_iterations   = 200
    forcing_term_strategy          = "EWCHOICE1"

Note that input values can also be set using accessor functions. Values that are set via this mechanism will be cached both in the solver context as well as in the corresponding PETSc object. Thus values changed on-the-fly will be written to restart. These input values can also be changed by directly accessing the corresponding PETSc object and using native PETSc function calls; however such settings/changes will NOT be cached in the solver context, and so will not be written to restart.

See also:
SNESAbstractFunctions
NonlinearSolverStrategy

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

SAMRAI::solv::SNES_SAMRAIContext::SNES_SAMRAIContext ( const std::string &  object_name,
SNESAbstractFunctions *  my_functions,
const boost::shared_ptr< tbox::Database > &  input_db = boost::shared_ptr<tbox::Database>() 
)

Constructor for SNES_SAMRAIContext allocates the SNES object and initializes rudimentary state associated with user-supplied solver components. Then, it reads solver parameter from input and restart which may override default values.

Precondition:
!object_name.empty()
my_functions != 0

References SAMRAI::tbox::RestartManager::getManager(), and TBOX_ASSERT.

SAMRAI::solv::SNES_SAMRAIContext::~SNES_SAMRAIContext (  ) 

Destructor for solve_SNES_SAMRAIContext destroys the SNES and the PETSc solution vector wrapper.

Initialize the state of the SNES solver based on vector argument representing the solution of the nonlinear system. In general, this routine must be called before the solve() routine is invoked.

int SAMRAI::solv::SNES_SAMRAIContext::solve (  )  [virtual]

Solve the nonlinear problem. In general, the initialize() routine must be called before this solve function to set up the solver. Returns 1 if successful, 0 otherwise.

Implements SAMRAI::solv::NonlinearSolverStrategy.
